elements.content: The first examples of coordination polymers of manganese­(II) and a nickel­(II) complex with a purely inorganic carboranylphosphinate ligand are reported, together with its exhaustive characterization. X-ray analysis revealed 1D polymeric chains with carboranylphosphinate ligands bridging two manganese­(II) centers. The reactivity of polymer 1 with water and Lewis bases has also been studied.
elements.clean_text: The first examples of coordination polymers of manganese(II) and a nickel(II) complex with a purely inorganic carboranylphosphinate ligand are reported, together with its exhaustive characterization. X-ray analysis revealed 1D polymeric chains with carboranylphosphinate ligands bridging two manganese(II) centers. The reactivity of polymer 1 with water and Lewis bases has also been studied.

elements.content: The first examples of 1D all-inorganic-made inorganic coordination polymers of manganese­(II) as well as their reactivities, polydispersities, and magnetic properties are reported. The polymers’ backbone is strictly made of Mn and the all-inorganic-made m-carboranylphosphinate as a versatile building block bridging each of two manganese­(II) centers that runs in a zigzag 1D chain.
elements.clean_text: The first examples of 1D all-inorganic-made inorganic coordination polymers of manganese(II) as well as their reactivities, polydispersities, and magnetic properties are reported. The polymers' backbone is strictly made of Mn and the all-inorganic-made m-carboranylphosphinate as a versatile building block bridging each of two manganese(II) centers that runs in a zigzag 1D chain.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) are different from organic polymers because metal atoms participate in their backbone, resulting in different properties. They require ligands, and among these, carboxylic ligands are frequent choices for metal–organic network spacers. Although phosphorus is an essential element in materials science and inorganic chemistry, as well as a key building block in all known forms of life (e.g., DNA is a fundamental life polymer), phosphorus chemistry is not receiving much attention to construct CPs. This is somewhat surprising because the coordinating motif of organic phosphorus oxoacids reminds one very much of the carboxylic acid site. Perhaps one possible clue to the weak presence of organic phosphorus oxoacids in CPs is that hypophosphorous acid is a powerful reducing agent that strongly limits its coordination to metal ions. Phosphorus oxoacids are the most common form of phosphorus acids. Within the mononuclear phosphorus oxoacids, those that have only one phosphorus and whose representative examples are hypophosphorous acid, phosphorous acid, and phosphoric acid, the phosphorus oxidation states are 1+, 3+, and 5+, respectively (). Substitution of one hydrogen or OH by organic groups leads to the corresponding organophosphonic and organophosphinic acids; their salts are known as phosphinates and phosphonates, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers (CPs) are different from organic polymers because metal atoms participate in their backbone, resulting in different properties. They require ligands, and among these, carboxylic ligands are frequent choices for metal-organic network spacers. Although phosphorus is an essential element in materials science and inorganic chemistry, as well as a key building block in all known forms of life (e.g., DNA is a fundamental life polymer), phosphorus chemistry is not receiving much attention to construct CPs. This is somewhat surprising because the coordinating motif of organic phosphorus oxoacids reminds one very much of the carboxylic acid site. Perhaps one possible clue to the weak presence of organic phosphorus oxoacids in CPs is that hypophosphorous acid is a powerful reducing agent that strongly limits its coordination to metal ions. Phosphorus oxoacids are the most common form of phosphorus acids. Within the mononuclear phosphorus oxoacids, those that have only one phosphorus and whose representative examples are hypophosphorous acid, phosphorous acid, and phosphoric acid, the phosphorus oxidation states are 1+, 3+, and 5+, respectively (). Substitution of one hydrogen or OH by organic groups leads to the corresponding organophosphonic and organophosphinic acids; their salts are known as phosphinates and phosphonates, respectively.

elements.content: Phosphinates are made on an industrial scale (∼50.000 tons/year) but have not yet been employed in general industrial organophosphorus synthesis. Althought phosphonic and phosphinic acids are seemingly good competitors to carboxylic acids in the sense of the complexation capacity and stability of produced complexes, a search of the Cambridge Structural Database shows just 375 hits for phosphonic acid R-PO­(OH)2 (R = alkyl, aryl) and >2200 hits for its transition-metal complexes, while only 20 hits for phosphinic acids R-P­(H)­O­(OH) (R = alkyl, aryl) and 47 hits for its transition-metal complexes were found.
elements.clean_text: Phosphinates are made on an industrial scale (~50.000 tons/year) but have not yet been employed in general industrial organophosphorus synthesis. Althought phosphonic and phosphinic acids are seemingly good competitors to carboxylic acids in the sense of the complexation capacity and stability of produced complexes, a search of the Cambridge Structural Database shows just 375 hits for phosphonic acid R-PO(OH)2 (R = alkyl, aryl) and >2200 hits for its transition-metal complexes, while only 20 hits for phosphinic acids R-P(H)O(OH) (R = alkyl, aryl) and 47 hits for its transition-metal complexes were found.

elements.content: The 12-vertex closo-C2B10H12 icosahedral carboranes, o-(1,2), m-(1,7), or p-(1,12), are like spheres of exceptional thermal and chemical stability that can be functionalized at the carbon and/or boron vertices by different straightforward reactions. All of these peculiarities and the fact that they can be produced at large scale make them valuable ligands in coordination chemistry. o- and m-carboranylphosphinates () were prepared as a new class of purely inorganic ligands, and the influence of the cluster on the reactivity of the phosphinate group was studied. The electron-withdrawing character of the carboranyl carbon atoms of the cluster cage, combined with their spherical space-filling efficiency, that have a volume similar to that of a rotating phenyl group with enhanced 3D aromaticity renders the phosphorus more difficult to oxidize. This enables carboranylphosphinates to survive against strong oxidizing elements, a property that is uncommon for organic phosphinates.
elements.clean_text: The 12-vertex closo-C2B10H12 icosahedral carboranes, o-(1,2), m-(1,7), or p-(1,12), are like spheres of exceptional thermal and chemical stability that can be functionalized at the carbon and/or boron vertices by different straightforward reactions. All of these peculiarities and the fact that they can be produced at large scale make them valuable ligands in coordination chemistry. o- and m-carboranylphosphinates () were prepared as a new class of purely inorganic ligands, and the influence of the cluster on the reactivity of the phosphinate group was studied. The electron-withdrawing character of the carboranyl carbon atoms of the cluster cage, combined with their spherical space-filling efficiency, that have a volume similar to that of a rotating phenyl group with enhanced 3D aromaticity renders the phosphorus more difficult to oxidize. This enables carboranylphosphinates to survive against strong oxidizing elements, a property that is uncommon for organic phosphinates.

elements.content: Schematic drawing of o- and m-carboranylphosphinic acid and their coordination modes: syn–syn and syn–anti.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic drawing of o- and m-carboranylphosphinic acid and their coordination modes: syn-syn and syn-anti.

elements.content: To date, no examples of carboranylphosphinic acid complexes or CPs with this motif have ever been described. This is not surprising because, as we have already noted above, very few complexes of phosphinate exist. The use of carboranes in supramolecular chemistry is a topic that generates great interest for their particular properties, which may induce unconventional characteristics in the supramolecular structures in which they are inserted. The geometrical features found in the complexes of [1-CO2-1,2-closo-C2B10H11]− with manganese­(II), copper­(II), and cobalt­(II) could not be compared with those of derivatives of conventional monocarboxylate ligands. The carboranyl group with its spherical shape is difficult to compare with organic fragments if we do not consider C60 or dodecahedrane C20H20; besides, it displays good hydrophobicity and electron-withdrawing properties through the carbon-atom vertices. There is a remarkable difference between the two isomers 1,2-closo-C2B10H12 and 1,7-closo-C2B10H12 that induces higher chemical stability to the P–Cc bond in 1,7-closo-carboranylphosphinic acids (). All of these characteristics of the icosahedral carborane, not found in imaginable organic fragments, suggest that a marked distinct behavior can be suspected in most of the generated complexes compared with aryl- and/or alkylphosphinic acids. In this paper, we show that inorganic CPs uniquely made with inorganic fragments are possible. Only organic solvent molecules occupying nonstructural sites have been needed. This has been possible by using the recently available m-carboranylphosphinate ligand [1-OPH­(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11]−, with manganese­(II) and nickel­(II). The reactivity of the 1D polymer manganese­(II) complex versus water and nitrogen heterocyclic aromatic ligands such as 2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bpy) is also presented.
elements.clean_text: To date, no examples of carboranylphosphinic acid complexes or CPs with this motif have ever been described. This is not surprising because, as we have already noted above, very few complexes of phosphinate exist. The use of carboranes in supramolecular chemistry is a topic that generates great interest for their particular properties, which may induce unconventional characteristics in the supramolecular structures in which they are inserted. The geometrical features found in the complexes of [1-CO2-1,2-closo-C2B10H11]- with manganese(II), copper(II), and cobalt(II) could not be compared with those of derivatives of conventional monocarboxylate ligands. The carboranyl group with its spherical shape is difficult to compare with organic fragments if we do not consider C60 or dodecahedrane C20H20; besides, it displays good hydrophobicity and electron-withdrawing properties through the carbon-atom vertices. There is a remarkable difference between the two isomers 1,2-closo-C2B10H12 and 1,7-closo-C2B10H12 that induces higher chemical stability to the P-Cc bond in 1,7-closo-carboranylphosphinic acids (). All of these characteristics of the icosahedral carborane, not found in imaginable organic fragments, suggest that a marked distinct behavior can be suspected in most of the generated complexes compared with aryl- and/or alkylphosphinic acids. In this paper, we show that inorganic CPs uniquely made with inorganic fragments are possible. Only organic solvent molecules occupying nonstructural sites have been needed. This has been possible by using the recently available m-carboranylphosphinate ligand [1-OPH(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11]-, with manganese(II) and nickel(II). The reactivity of the 1D polymer manganese(II) complex versus water and nitrogen heterocyclic aromatic ligands such as 2,2'-bipyridine (2,2'-bpy) is also presented.

elements.content: The strategic procedures for the synthesis of the manganese­(II), 1–3, and nickel­(II), 4, complexes, all of them containing the anionic m-carboranylphosphinate ligand [1-OPH­(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11]−, are outlined in . The manganese­(II) complex 1 was obtained by mixing methanol solutions of Na­[1-OPH­(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11] salt with MnCl2·4H2O in a 2:1 ratio after stirring for 2 h at room temperature. Afterward, NaCl was filtered and the solvent evaporated under a vacuum to obtain a white solid 1. When 1 was dissolved in iPrOH/H2O, compound 2 was obtained. However, when an equimolar ethanol solution of bidentate 2,2′-bpy was added to 1, a slightly yellow solution of 3 was formed. The polymeric structure of 3 is lost in a mixture of iPrOH/H2O, producing lower-nuclearity species, as supported by 11B­{1H} NMR spectroscopy (see Supporting Information, SI).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of All-Inorganic-Made Inorganic CPs

The strategic procedures for the synthesis of the manganese(II), 1-3, and nickel(II), 4, complexes, all of them containing the anionic m-carboranylphosphinate ligand [1-OPH(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11]-, are outlined in . The manganese(II) complex 1 was obtained by mixing methanol solutions of Na[1-OPH(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11] salt with MnCl2⋅4H2O in a 2:1 ratio after stirring for 2 h at room temperature. Afterward, NaCl was filtered and the solvent evaporated under a vacuum to obtain a white solid 1. When 1 was dissolved in iPrOH/H2O, compound 2 was obtained. However, when an equimolar ethanol solution of bidentate 2,2'-bpy was added to 1, a slightly yellow solution of 3 was formed. The polymeric structure of 3 is lost in a mixture of iPrOH/H2O, producing lower-nuclearity species, as supported by 11B{1H} NMR spectroscopy (see  Supporting Information, SI).

elements.content: On the other hand, the reaction of Na­[1-OPH­(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11] and NiCl2 in a 2:1 ratio in ethanol at room temperature leads to the formation of compound 4 after NaCl filtration and solvent evaporation. Elemental analyses and electrospray ionization mass spectroscopy confirm the stoichiometries of all of these complexes.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the reaction of Na[1-OPH(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11] and NiCl2 in a 2:1 ratio in ethanol at room temperature leads to the formation of compound 4 after NaCl filtration and solvent evaporation. Elemental analyses and electrospray ionization mass spectroscopy confirm the stoichiometries of all of these complexes.

elements.content: The IR spectra of 1–4 display typical ν­(B–H) absorption at frequencies above 2580 cm–1, characteristic of closo-carborane derivatives. Strong absorptions observed in the region 1225–1000 cm–1 indicate the presence of PO and M–O–P linkages, and the absorption around 2330–2400 cm–1 is associated with ν­(P–H) in all cases. The 11B­{1H} NMR spectra of complexes 2–4 are observed in the range −2 to −15 ppm. The nickel­(II) compound shows a 2:2:4:2 pattern, whereas 11B and 11B­{1H} NMR spectra of manganese­(II) complex 1 displays a downfield spectrum (+14.0/+1.7 ppm) with boron resonances overlapping. The phosphorus resonance of 1–3 at the 31P­{1H} NMR spectra was not observed because of the paramagnetism as well as the quadrupole moment of the metal nuclei (I = 5/2 for 55 Mn; natural abundance = 100%), while the nickel­(II) complex 4 displays a very broad resonance around 13 ppm (see the SI).
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic Evidence of the All-Inorganic-Made Inorganic CPs

The IR spectra of 1-4 display typical ν(B-H) absorption at frequencies above 2580 cm-1, characteristic of closo-carborane derivatives. Strong absorptions observed in the region 1225-1000 cm-1 indicate the presence of PO and M-O-P linkages, and the absorption around 2330-2400 cm-1 is associated with ν(P-H) in all cases. The 11B{1H} NMR spectra of complexes 2-4 are observed in the range -2 to -15 ppm. The nickel(II) compound shows a 2:2:4:2 pattern, whereas 11B and 11B{1H} NMR spectra of manganese(II) complex 1 displays a downfield spectrum (+14.0/+1.7 ppm) with boron resonances overlapping. The phosphorus resonance of 1-3 at the 31P{1H} NMR spectra was not observed because of the paramagnetism as well as the quadrupole moment of the metal nuclei (I = 5/2 for 55 Mn; natural abundance = 100%), while the nickel(II) complex 4 displays a very broad resonance around 13 ppm (see the SI).

elements.content: The polymeric nature of 1 and 3 could not be absolutely defined unless good crystals were grown. Compounds 1 and 3, in addition to be the first examples of all-inorganic-made inorganic CPs, are also the first described coordination polynuclear manganese­(II) polymers with phosphinate ligands bridging each of the two manganese­(II) centers. The backbone is strictly made of manganese and the all-inorganic-made carboranylphosphinate that runs in a zigzag 1D chain. In 1, the two μ-OO′ phosphinate groups in the “Mn2(μ-OOPR)2” core are different; one of them is coordinated to manganese­(II) atoms in a syn–syn conformation and the other one in a syn–anti conformation (). To fill the two vacant manganese­(II) positions that do not have a structural function, both methanol (1) and 2,2′-bpy (3) have been utilized. To the best of our knowledge, no similar structure has been found in the literature with other phosphinate ligands. Interestingly, the structure of 3 is the same as that for 1, except in one noticeable fact. In 1, the methanol molecules are trans, whereas in 3, 2,2′-bpy necessarily occupies a cis disposition. The fact that the structure of 3 is similar to that of 1 is in contrast to the fate of manganese coordination complexes with carboranylcarboxylate that, upon reaction with 2,2′-bpy, the initial polymeric nature is lost to develop species with much lower nuclearity. The result of dissolving 1 in iPrOH/H2O leads to 2. The crystal structure indicates that the former polymeric structure in 1 is broken, leading to a mononuclear manganese­(II) compound, [Mn­(H2O)4(1-OPH­(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11)2]. In 2, the carboranylphosphinate ligand is monodentate, whereas it is bridging in 1 and 3. The molecular structures of 1–3 are shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

The polymeric nature of 1 and 3 could not be absolutely defined unless good crystals were grown. Compounds 1 and 3, in addition to be the first examples of all-inorganic-made inorganic CPs, are also the first described coordination polynuclear manganese(II) polymers with phosphinate ligands bridging each of the two manganese(II) centers. The backbone is strictly made of manganese and the all-inorganic-made carboranylphosphinate that runs in a zigzag 1D chain. In 1, the two μ-OO' phosphinate groups in the "Mn2(μ-OOPR)2" core are different; one of them is coordinated to manganese(II) atoms in a syn-syn conformation and the other one in a syn-anti conformation (). To fill the two vacant manganese(II) positions that do not have a structural function, both methanol (1) and 2,2'-bpy (3) have been utilized. To the best of our knowledge, no similar structure has been found in the literature with other phosphinate ligands. Interestingly, the structure of 3 is the same as that for 1, except in one noticeable fact. In 1, the methanol molecules are trans, whereas in 3, 2,2'-bpy necessarily occupies a cis disposition. The fact that the structure of 3 is similar to that of 1 is in contrast to the fate of manganese coordination complexes with carboranylcarboxylate that, upon reaction with 2,2'-bpy, the initial polymeric nature is lost to develop species with much lower nuclearity. The result of dissolving 1 in iPrOH/H2O leads to 2. The crystal structure indicates that the former polymeric structure in 1 is broken, leading to a mononuclear manganese(II) compound, [Mn(H2O)4(1-OPH(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11)2]. In 2, the carboranylphosphinate ligand is monodentate, whereas it is bridging in 1 and 3. The molecular structures of 1-3 are shown in .

elements.content: For nickel­(II), the affinity to the carboranylphosphinate ligand is very weak, much less than that for water. The polymeric structure is not generated in this case, and a salt of [Ni­(H2O)6]2+ compensating for the carboranylphosphinate ligand is generated. Noticeable is the packing of 4 along the a axis in which the hydrophobic layers pack one on top of the other. Views of the packing along the a, b, and c axes are displayed in the SI.
elements.clean_text: For nickel(II), the affinity to the carboranylphosphinate ligand is very weak, much less than that for water. The polymeric structure is not generated in this case, and a salt of [Ni(H2O)6]2+ compensating for the carboranylphosphinate ligand is generated. Noticeable is the packing of 4 along the a axis in which the hydrophobic layers pack one on top of the other. Views of the packing along the a, b, and c axes are displayed in the SI.

elements.content: X-ray structures of manganese compounds 1–3 (a–c, respectively), showing a monodimensional arrangement.
elements.clean_text: 2  X-ray structures of manganese compounds 1-3 (a-c, respectively), showing a monodimensional arrangement.

elements.content: Because these polymers can be interpreted as made of a fully inorganic scaffold structure plus solvating or ancillary ligands, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA)/differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) studies were made to interpret whether these solvating elements were really the easiest ones to remove. Some information had been drawn from the 1 to 3 reaction process, by which the initial scaffold had been retained and only the initial solvating ligands had been exchanged. TGA/DSC data are displayed in the SI. For 1, the best fit for a weight loss of 38.49% in the range from room temperature to 483 °C is the removal of two methanol coordinated molecules and one 1,7-closo-C2B10H12 per manganese­(II). For 2, a weight loss of 40.90% in the range from room temperature to 507 °C corresponds to four coordinated water molecules and one 1,7-closo-C2B10H12 per manganese­(II). Finally, a weight loss of 47.71% in the range from room temperature to 430 °C observed for 3 can be assigned to the loss of one bpy molecule and one 1,7-closo-C2B10H12.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Studies of the All-Inorganic-Made Inorganic CPs

Thermal Stability

Because these polymers can be interpreted as made of a fully inorganic scaffold structure plus solvating or ancillary ligands, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA)/differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) studies were made to interpret whether these solvating elements were really the easiest ones to remove. Some information had been drawn from the 1 to 3 reaction process, by which the initial scaffold had been retained and only the initial solvating ligands had been exchanged. TGA/DSC data are displayed in the SI. For 1, the best fit for a weight loss of 38.49% in the range from room temperature to 483 °C is the removal of two methanol coordinated molecules and one 1,7-closo-C2B10H12 per manganese(II). For 2, a weight loss of 40.90% in the range from room temperature to 507 °C corresponds to four coordinated water molecules and one 1,7-closo-C2B10H12 per manganese(II). Finally, a weight loss of 47.71% in the range from room temperature to 430 °C observed for 3 can be assigned to the loss of one bpy molecule and one 1,7-closo-C2B10H12.

elements.content: Methanol solutions of 1 and 3 at different concentrations (from 0.01 to 20 g/L) were measured by DLS, indicating that aggregation/cleavage processes of polymeric structures 1 and 3 in methanol strongly depend on the concentration (). This dynamic process causes polydispersity; however, an estimation of the dimensions of the polymer/aggregates can be obtained. The TEM images of a methanol solution of CPs 1 and 3 at the same concentration (1 g/L) corroborate that either polymeric or aggregate structures exist in solution (). For 1, long strands of 100–200 nm width are formed, whereas 3 aggregates in spherical structures whose dimensions are in the range 1700–2000 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) of 1 and 3 

Methanol solutions of 1 and 3 at different concentrations (from 0.01 to 20 g/L) were measured by DLS, indicating that aggregation/cleavage processes of polymeric structures 1 and 3 in methanol strongly depend on the concentration (). This dynamic process causes polydispersity; however, an estimation of the dimensions of the polymer/aggregates can be obtained. The TEM images of a methanol solution of CPs 1 and 3 at the same concentration (1 g/L) corroborate that either polymeric or aggregate structures exist in solution (). For 1, long strands of 100-200 nm width are formed, whereas 3 aggregates in spherical structures whose dimensions are in the range 1700-2000 nm.

elements.content: DLS study of polymers 1 and 3 from methanol at different concentrations with their TEM images from methanol at the same concentration (1 g/L).
elements.clean_text: 3  DLS study of polymers 1 and 3 from methanol at different concentrations with their TEM images from methanol at the same concentration (1 g/L).

elements.content: To date, organophosphinate CPs with transition metals were not available because of the reducing power of the ligands. Here, we report on the first 1D phosphinate CPs of manganese­(II) (1 and 3). This goal has been achieved by using a unique purely inorganic ligand, m-carboranylphosphinate, which is not a reducing agent because of the electron-withdrawing character of the closo-carboranyl cluster. In addition, m-carboranylphosphinate is an amphiphilic ligand as a result of the hydrophilic site of the coordinating group and the lypophilic properties of the closo-carboranyl cluster. The central wire is made of manganese­(II) ions linked by bridging PO2 units. Each PO2 unit is also linked to a spherical closo-carborane overall, producing an all-inorganic-made inorganic CP. Only organic solvent molecules occupying nonstructural sites have been needed. In contrast to manganese­(II), nickel­(II) possesses a higher affinity for water than for the m-carboranylphosphinate ligand; consequently, no polymeric structure is generated, but the salt [Ni­(H2O)6]­[1-OPH­(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11] with a supramolecular hydrophobic/hydrophilic structure is obtained. Work is now underway to explore the coordination capability of m-carboranylphosphinate with other first- and second-row transition metals.
elements.clean_text: To date, organophosphinate CPs with transition metals were not available because of the reducing power of the ligands. Here, we report on the first 1D phosphinate CPs of manganese(II) (1 and 3). This goal has been achieved by using a unique purely inorganic ligand, m-carboranylphosphinate, which is not a reducing agent because of the electron-withdrawing character of the closo-carboranyl cluster. In addition, m-carboranylphosphinate is an amphiphilic ligand as a result of the hydrophilic site of the coordinating group and the lypophilic properties of the closo-carboranyl cluster. The central wire is made of manganese(II) ions linked by bridging PO2 units. Each PO2 unit is also linked to a spherical closo-carborane overall, producing an all-inorganic-made inorganic CP. Only organic solvent molecules occupying nonstructural sites have been needed. In contrast to manganese(II), nickel(II) possesses a higher affinity for water than for the m-carboranylphosphinate ligand; consequently, no polymeric structure is generated, but the salt [Ni(H2O)6][1-OPH(O)-1,7-closo-C2B10H11] with a supramolecular hydrophobic/hydrophilic structure is obtained. Work is now underway to explore the coordination capability of m-carboranylphosphinate with other first- and second-row transition metals.
